summary: Leo Cherne was the president of the Research Institute of America (RIA). The CIA used RIA and Cherne to provide cover for CIA operatives, including employment backstories and potential overseas cover. He is mentioned in the context of the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) request for information on individuals and entities. The documents suggest that the CIA had a working relationship with Cherne and RIA, using the organization to facilitate its operations by providing cover for its agents.
significance: Leo Cherne's significance in the JFK context stems from his role as the president of the Research Institute of America (RIA), which was used by the CIA to provide cover for its operatives. This connection raises questions about the extent of the CIA's involvement with private organizations and individuals during the period relevant to the JFK assassination.
